participants.participant: Kiran Bhojani, Executive Vice President, Investor Relations
Dr. Wulf H. Bernotat, Chief Executive Officer
Dr. Marcus Schenck, Chief Financial Officer

plist.p: Good afternoon, buenas tardes, bonjouno, and dobre den. Welcome to our Analyst and Investments Conference on our Results 2008. We would also like to welcome all analysts, investors, and our colleagues on Internet and Intranet. We would also like to welcome our we call them knowledge people on the right hand side -- they know all the answers -- and operation managers in this room.

Certainly, I should not forget to greet the best friends of E.ON that is my family members in India watching this conference. My special thanks to all of you who have come today to attend my last Analyst Conference, including our biggest investors from Norway.

Yes, it is now 17 years I have spent with this wonderful group and I'm leaving E.ON at the end of June this year. I can assure you that I had the best time and I have seen and learned everything what a group like E.ON goes through. I am leaving for my family reasons. Sascha Bibert, who's sitting in the front, who has joined us from Munich Re at the beginning of this year, will then take over at my role as a Head of Investor Relations starting July 1.

I would like to take the opportunity to personally thank all analysts, shareholders, and bankers for their trust, for their confidence, and, most importantly for me, the open and warm relationship we have developed over the years. I've certainly learned a lot from all of you.

I've always tried my best to protect the interest of E.ON, but at the same time integrate your concerns and credits into the management feedback. And I hope in this respect I have not disappointed you. Certainly, I'd have loved to see this best stock price performance in nominal and real terms before I leave, but that's life.

My biggest thanks go to the entire Board of Management who has supported my team and me all these years. Yes, I'm proud to say that I'm associated with the management who is absolutely dedicated to the shareholder value concept and takes seriously the concerns of the capital market. In this respect, I would like to thank especially, Ulrich Hartmann, who hired me 17 years ago and Wulf Bernotat, who was giving me the great support in my role.

I would also like to thank all my colleagues throughout the Group and in this room for their support, and last but not least, my competent IR team who has always stayed by my side during all these years. If you ask me what am I going to miss the most, honestly the most I'm going to miss is drinking those extra dirty martinis with Wulf Bernotat on the road show in the evening.

Thanks again for everything, and now back to work, but before I hand over to Wulf and Marcus for the presentations, I would request you to turn off your Blackberries and mobile phones and please since I know all of you almost but please insert your card you got in, so I know who is sitting where.
Thank you and I hand it over to Wulf for his presentation. Thanks.

Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. After a little very personal farewell speech back to the business and so I would like to welcome you to the Analyst and Investor Conference for '08 full year results. On February 10 this year we already communicated to you some preliminary figures for the '08 annual results and let me therefore briefly pass through the main financials for '08.

We can look back at a strong operational performance last year. Adjusted EBITDA grew by 8% year-on -year to €13.4 billion, adjusted EBIT increased by 7% to €9.9 billion, and adjusted net income reached €5.6 billion, up 9%. However, as a consequence of the impairments that we have already announced as well as other non-operating items, net income attributable to shareholders declined from 7.2 to €1.3 billion.

The Supervisory Board proposes to pay out a dividend of €1.50 per share. At 51%, the proposed dividend payout is in line with our objective of distributing 50 to 60% of adjusted net income. With an increase of 9% compared to last year, our shareholders will be able to share with the Company's success.

Finally, the acquisition of Viesgo and selected Endesa assets propelled E.ON economic investments to an all-time high of €26 billion. Economic net debt thus increased from 23 to €45 billion, close to our targeted financial structure.

Ladies and gentlemen, let me now discuss our strategy for the coming years. During '07 and '08, E.ON has successfully positioned itself on the European scale like no other competitor. In parallel, the Group has accelerated organic investments to renew and grow its power generation portfolio, acquire a global scale in renewables, and strengthen its gas business. However, over the last six months, we have witnessed deep upheaval in the international financial and capital markets.

At an unprecedented pace, the entire economy has fallen into a recession, which appears to be spreading wider, going deeper, and lasting longer than most had anticipated. Although E.ON remains probably more shielded than many other companies, the economic crisis will not leave us unaffected.

Four developments in particular are affecting our business prospects. First, the collapse of oil prices and of all other energy prices; second, the devaluation of currencies in a number of countries where we operate; third, the unusual contraction of power and gas demand; and finally, the widening of credit spreads following the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers.

As a consequence, we now expect 2009 adjusted EBIT to match the level of 2008 and we have to acknowledge that it will not be feasible to achieve the 2010 adjusted EBIT of €12.4 billion before portfolio measures that we had committed to in May 2007. We now expect to achieve a 2010 adjusted EBIT of €11 billion before portfolio measures.

And Marcus Schenck provides you with a more detailed explanation in a moment. Clearly, most of the changes to our 2009 outlook and 2010 target are due to external factors of which we have no control. But we are not standing still. We are going to tackle the crisis head-on by focusing our strategy on the following three axes.

First, we want to improve the operational performance by our own efforts. Second, we want to further focus our business model and streamline our portfolio. And finally, we want to concentrate on organic investments and prioritize them more stringently.

Let me start with our first strategic priority, improving operational performance. We have already informed you on the key elements when we presented you the Perform-to-Win initiative one month ago. Perform-to-Win will address the entire value chain and all functions within the Group. The steering team has already identified more than 100 potential performance improvement measures. Although many specific projects are still in the validation phase, we expect that Perform-to-Win will help to improve adjusted EBIT by up to €1.5 billion in 2011.

The improvement of performance will be somewhat back-end loaded. Cost savings would contribute about €1.1 billion out of the 1.5 total while the other 400 million would be generated by a better utilization of our assets. In addition to improving adjusted EBIT, Perform-to-Win also aims to enhance and accelerate decision-making by streamlining decision structures, clarifying responsibilities, and simplifying lines of reporting.

Over the last years, E.ON has gained in size and we firmly believe that this will support value creation in the future, but our vision of making E.ON the leading power and gas company is not only about size, it is also about quality. With Perform-to-Win, we want E.ON to move to the top of the rankings in operational excellence.

Ladies and gentlemen, let me now move to our second priority, portfolio streamlining. In less than 12 months, we have doubled the number of market units from five to 10. Most market units count several business units, which in some cases comprises a number of activities.

There is no doubt that E.ON has become a complex group. To some extent, we can try to simplify what is existing, but we have come to the conclusion that we need to focus on fewer activities and that we must run harder those we decide to stay in, and that is what the portfolio review is all about.

In practice, we are testing each business and each asset for its strategic fit on the one hand and for its financial performance and prospects on the other hand. The portfolio review has already yielded substantial results.

At the end of 2008, we completed the asset swap with Statkraft, which provides us with full control over E.ON Sweden. We've signed agreements with Electrabel and EnBW to swap 1.7 gigawatt and seek 0.5 gigawatt of generation capacity in Germany.

We are currently negotiating the swap of 2.9% of our Gazprom stake for 20% minus one share in the Yuzhno Russkoye gas field in Siberia. We are preparing the disposal of the power transmission network in Germany and we are looking at the possibility of a disposal Thüga.

For several of these steps, we succeeded to combine portfolio streamlining with other strategic objectives. The asset swap with Electrabel, for example, helps us to fulfill the compromise with the EU Commission while allowing us to extend our presence in generation outside Germany. Another example is the Gazprom-Yuzhno Russkoye asset swap, which would bring us close to our target of producing 10 bcm of equity gas per year.

Our short-term priority regarding the portfolio review is to execute on the already announced transactions as most of them are still pending. I'm thus not going to announce any specific new steps today. Nevertheless, rest assured that the portfolio review is gathering strength. All in all, our goal is to achieve more than €10 billion of cash-effective divestments by the end of 2010, capital market conditions permitting. This includes those disposals that we have already announced plus a number of options that we are currently evaluating but which are not yet ready to communicate on.

Let me now come to E.ON's third strategic axis, prioritize our investments. Last year, we invested €26 billion. Thereof, €11.5 billion was spent on the acquisition of the Viesgo and selected Endesa assets and €4.4 billion on the cash neutral Statkraft asset swap. The other €10 billion were mainly invested in our priority areas for organic growth, conventional power generation, renewables, and the gas business.

We planned initially to invest €36 billion over the period 2009 to 2011 in line with the run rate of the previous investment plan for this period. However, we have decided to limit investment for the period '09 through 2011 to €30 billion or approximately €10 billion per year. Obviously, due to the economic downturn, it makes sense to postpone or cancel some investments. Furthermore, even at €30 billion the overall level of investments remains high and we want to keep our financing in balance.

We have rechecked the value creation potential of a sample of our investment projects. In power generation, for example, most projects that are currently under construction were ordered when component prices were at attractive levels. This stress-testing exercise indicated that even in a more stressful environment, these investments fulfill all our financial criteria. We are thus confident that the investments that are fully committed to, and especially the 18 power plants under construction, will create value for shareholders.

The six billion reduction of our investments for the period '09 to 2011 will thus mostly apply to projects for which we have easy options to postpone or cancel. Before taking firm decisions, we will carry out a thorough re-assessment of each project and establish a stringent privatization among all the potential investments. This should ensure that the projects with the highest value creation potential come on top of the list.

Ladies and gentlemen, before handing over to Marcus Schenck, I would like to say a few words about our dividend policy. Our dividend policy remains unchanged: we want to payout between 50 and 60% of adjusted net income as dividends. However, as we do not expect to achieve €12.4 billion of adjusted EBIT in 2010, we cannot confirm our previous expectation of growing the dividend by 10% or 10 to 20% even per year on average between '06 and 2010.

It is also likely that we will postpone the completion of our share buyback program for much longer that we initially anticipated. Nevertheless, we believe that in these difficult times, our dividends will remain attractive compared to many companies and sectors and will allow our shareholders to share in our success.
I will now hand over to Marcus Schenck, who will discuss our 2008 results in more detail and present our outlook for 2009 and 2010. So, Marcus, over to you.

So, good afternoon also from my side. I will first walk you through the 2008 results and then subsequently comment on '09 and 2010. Highlights for 2008, earnings figures are essentially up as planned, adjusted EBIT and adjusted net income. Operating cash flow is down, as I will explain to you later, primarily caused by working capital changes. And then three, with 26 billion of economic investments, we've seen the peak investment year, which was also then the main driver behind the increase in leverage.

As announced earlier, in February of this year, adjusted EBIT is up 7% in line with our guidance last March. The year-on-year comparison -- and this is the last time I'm going to say that -- is as you know not exactly meaningful given that the parameter of the market units in 2007 was slightly different to that of 2008. From Q1 of this year onwards that situation will be different, i.e., then you can compare the units.

Before I dive into each and every market unit, just one overall comment. We've seen in 2008, a -- quite a hit resulting from the changes in currencies, British pounds, Swedish krona -- I'm pretty sure many of you that at least those who've made their way from the U.K., know what I'm talking about -- that has cost us some 220 million in 2008 compared to the prior year.

I will come back to that theme when I talk about 2009 and 2010, because people should not forget when we talk about 2008, at least as far as the P&L is concerned, we are looking at primarily average rates over the year. And some of the currencies I've been talking about, Swedish krona, British pounds, they've seen the biggest hits at the end of last year.

Let's now go into the different market units. Central Europe first. As we indicated in the context of our Q3 results, Central Europe had, on a quarter-on-quarter comparison, some negative effects. In particular, we had a temporary outage of the power plant -- nuclear power plant Unteveza and in particular, in Q4 of 2007, we had a significant release in nuclear pension provisions, which was obviously not repeated in Q4 of 2008. But you should just bear that in mind when you compare this unit on a quarter-on-quarter basis.

Looking at the full year, what are the main effects? Central Europe West, the non-regulated part, we have 1.2 billion power price effect that is roughly equivalent to an increase by €10 per megawatt hour. Against that 700 million charge in fuel costs -- increased fuel costs. We have about 160 million negative development compared to 2007 as a consequence of volume losses, in particular related to Krümmel and Brunsbüttel, and as I mentioned also with regard to Unteveza.

That was partially offset by slightly higher volumes, about 1.1 terawatt hours in Benelux. We had, when you look at the full year, seen net – a higher release in provision on the nuclear sites, about 350 million, which then when you compare this year-on-year 2008 means was that 50 million lower than 2007 because of that effect. And then we have about -- just to give you an indication, 160 million, that is essentially transferred to other market units, primarily E.ON Energy Trading.

Central Europe West, the regulated piece, we have seen a roughly 240 million cut in tariffs compared to the year before, and that is essentially being offset by the fact that in 2007 we had one-time – one-off provisions for investments or – for investments essentially into our grid business, with an overall volume of 300 million. Hence, West regulated was slightly up.

And then as far as our Eastern European business is concerned, here the main effect is a price increase and more favorable regulatory conditions in the year 2008 in Hungary. In addition to that, we have an effect of roughly plus 100 million of the first-time consolidation of the French SNET business.

Moving on to Pan-European Gas, here I would dare to say that we may likely see kind of a peak EBIT year in 2008, certainly when we sort of look at the next two years ahead. What are the main drivers? One key driver is the upstream business, which in total made 340 million of EBIT in 2008. That is roughly 250 million more than the year before; 100 million of that is price effect and 150 million is a volume effect.

Our Midstream business, here we have seen higher income in the transportation business, around €140 million, and a higher result from our storage valuations, approximately €190 million. Negative effects in that business are essentially margin related, which is a drop in margin by about €130 million and a slightly lower volume of €90 million.

In the downstream business, that is down compared to the year before. Here, the two main effects are, one is in our Hungarian business, Földgáz, where essentially the allowed price increases that are – or the price increases allowed by the regulator have not been -- have essentially not been sufficient, and we have in particular suffered from the very weak forints in the Hungarian business, total effect about €150 million.

And a last point, we had in 2007 extraordinary gains in the Thüga business as a consequence of a number of disposals in that business, and we had a one-time effect from tax reforms. Again, that positive effect in 2007 was not repeated in 2008; that's also in total 150 million.

Moving on to the U.K., here actually the primary driver for the delta in EBIT contribution is currency. That has cost us 90 million in the non-regulated business and 70 million in the regulated business. In addition, in the non-regulated business, the retail business was weaker, where essentially we have been suffering from higher procurement costs compared to the year before. That was -- we started to reverse that a bit in Q4 of 2008, but when you do a full year-on-year comparison, we are still down.

To be fair to the U.K. and the operating performance in pounds, in local currency, and corrected for those activities that have been pushed to E.ON Energy Trading, Climate & Renewables, and some part of the storage business to Ruhrgas, they are actually roughly at last year's level, again in local currency.

Nordic, the regulated business is flat, and in the non-regulated business we see an increase, 170 million, it's essentially driven by higher transfer prices to Energy Trading, roughly the equivalent of €6. And we have a drop in volume; they were down about two terawatt hours that cost us 70 million and then higher taxes on the hydro and nuclear sites of 50 million are the negative effects in that business.

U.S. Midwest, essentially on the same level as the year before. The dollar has cost us in euro terms roughly 30 million. Also industrial volumes were down. Here we have actually already seen the first impact from the economic crisis in what we call our retail business in the U.S., but it's mainly industrial customers; that's 20 million. Those negative 50 million are being offset by higher recovery from -- on our fuel and gas cost and the return on the investments into – let's call it the environmental CapEx that we have spent in the U.S. that's roughly €25 million.

Energy Trading, here our asset optimization part shows a result of €466 million and the prop trading is at almost €180 million. In the asset optimization, obviously we have -- one of the key factors that – in particular in the Nordic business, we have in the end realized better prices than before. And in the proprietary trading business, I think we clearly, like probably many others, benefited from the high volatility in the markets. We've achieved this strong result without ever coming close to the limits that we set for that business, the risk limits.

Let me now come to the new markets. The contribution is in total at a level of €90 million on the EBIT level. It looks little bit more pretty when you look at EBITDA. Let me go through the four market's units separately. 60 million we're roughly up in Climate & Renewables, essentially due to the fact that the asset base that is produced in earnings is bigger.

In Italy, we have a situation where our – we have for the first time consolidated for half a year the Endesa Italia business but we have one big negative effect, which we've been commenting on also in the context of the Q3 results. We have in total a charge of €155 million resulting from the fact that we had to step up the freely allocated CO2 certificates in the context of our acquisition and had to take that as a charge through the P&L. This is an effect which will not be repeated in 2009. Same holds true for Spain, where that effect is negative €70 million.
In Russia we are showing an EBIT of €40 million. Here just to give you sort of some sense, a big negative item is the charge of roughly €100 million from purchase price allocation.

Let me move on from the adjusted EBIT to the other P&L numbers. Adjusted net interest expense is essentially up by about €900 million due to the higher indebtedness of the Group, which is a consequence of our investment activities.

Net book gains are almost at the same level as they were in the year before albeit for different reasons. The primary driver this year is that the transaction with Statkraft has created a roughly 1.1 billion book gain in our results. Last year, the two main effects that we were showing were on the one hand book gains from the sale of securities and then secondly, book gain on the disposal of our telecom business .

Restructuring cost, here we see an increase of roughly €450 million. Main effects here are a charge of roughly €250 million in the context of the restructuring of our regional utility businesses in Germany as well as roughly 100 million charge in the context of bundling of our trading activities. This is essentially all project cost.

The goodwill, I will not at this stage go into more details. I hope we explained that sufficiently a few weeks ago. Here the total charge of €3.3 billion, just to recap, 1.5 billion for our US Midwest business and €1.8 billion in the context of the goodwill – the preliminary goodwill for the assets we have acquired from Endesa, Enel, and Acciona.

The other non-operating results is – here we see a significant change in our numbers. It's essentially two effects that are driving this. On the one hand, we have an impairment on securities we are holding on our balance sheets to back nuclear provisions and partially also pension obligations. That's a total charge of roughly €700 million.

And then we have a very large effect from the mark-to-market valuation of derivatives where we see a delta of roughly €2.7 billion compared to prior year. The main drivers there is the development of coal and the other one is development in gas prices.

Those effects together leads to a significant drop in reported net income. Again, the two main effects that explain the delta to prior year is on the one hand, impairments, and secondly, the mark-to-markets or the developments in the mark-to-market valuation of derivatives.

Moving on to the more relevant figure, adjusted net income. I think you're familiar with the logic in terms of the items that we correct for. Adjusted net income is up 9% compared to prior year. This is mainly driven by the fact that obviously EBIT is up, net result is down, and then in addition, the effective tax rates that is embedded in our adjusted net income is down compared to prior year. That's why all-in-all, we're up 9%.

Let me now move to cash flow. Group cash flow is down roughly €2 billion to now 6.7 billion. I must admit, I don't find it terribly instructive to walk you through this on a market unit basis given there are a number of things that essentially result from the fact that there is a lot of interaction between the market units in particular E.ON Energy Trading and hence I will do this from a Group perspective on the next chart. Maintenance CapEx, just to highlight that, is now at a level what was in 2008, at a level of roughly €1.6 billion.

This one here tries to reconcile the developments in operating cash flow looking at a from a Group perspective and we are -- essentially there is obviously 100 smaller effects that one could also mention, but I would like you to focus on sort of the key components.

On the positive sides, when we start with 2007 number, we're obviously up given the price effects in our generation business in particular as it relates to the outright power positions in Central Europe and Nordic. We have, on the other hand, seen lower volumes in the acquisition given the outages of some of the nuclear power plants in particular Krümmel and Brunsbüttel. We've seen, I mentioned that before, lower network fees in particular in Germany.

And now, the next three items are, I would say the key drivers and they're all working capital related. Pan-European Gas, here we have a situation where 2007 we started with a high volume of gas stored and we've taken that down until the end of 2007 quite substantially. In 2008, we consequently started with a storage volume that was lower than it was at the beginning of 2007 and it has been roughly stable until the end of 2008. Meaning by end of 2008, we have almost the same storage volume or same volume stored as we had at the end of 2007. However, the difference being that in 2007, we had clearly benefited from the fact that we had started with a higher volume, i.e., 2007 saw a -- compared to 2008, higher cash flow from divesting working capital and we have not repeated that in 2008. That's the first effect.

Second, in the U.K., we are seeing an increase in receivables in the retail business. This is almost exclusively price driven or -- this is exclusively price driven. Price levels were up hence the overall receivable volume is also up. The payment terms have not deteriorated. On the contrary we managed to slightly improve them.

And then the third item is another 800 million negative cash outflow, which is a function of us having throughout the year 2008 acquired a number of CO2 certificates, which will be used in the coming years. What we've done there is, we have -- instead of essentially buying derivatives to hedge our position, we bought the certificates, more liquid market. We thought that all in all it was the smarter way to do it.

What it means is, however, it means that 2008 suffers from cash outflow for that but that will be reversed in the coming years because then we will not have to pay those CO2 certificates, which essentially we simply acquired to hedge our position in selling power. So that effect, those 800 million will reverse in the years, in particular '09 and '10. And then there is a number of smaller other effects.

Let me comment on investments. Cash-effective investments are at a level of €18.4 billion. Main effect is obviously the acquisition of Endesa Europe and Viesgo but also very prominently our organic investments. We've acquired some debts in the context of the Endesa, Viesgo transaction and we also include as a part of our definition of economic investments the asset swap with Statkraft, which is the second to last line here in the table.

How has that impacted our economic net debt? We start with a level of €23.4 billion at the beginning of the year and then -- I mean, you can do the math in a way yourself the three things that take it down is economic investments leaving out the asset swap because that was not cash-effective, -- the dividend payments, and the share buyback and then -- that is partially being offset in particular by cash provided from the operating activities.

As a consequence, the debt factor is up from a level of 1.9 to now 3.2. Just to highlight that 3.2 is -- assumes that we have -- and I think that's the correct way of doing it -- we have pro forma adjusted for full year ownership of the Endesa, Viesgo assets. It's not a very big impact but technically something you should be aware of.

So that much to the 2008 results. Just quickly and given that Wulf has essentially commented on this – this one just shows you the proposed dividend and the development looking at prior years. I will not repeat what Wulf has been saying.

So let me come to the outlook for 2009 and then subsequently 2010. And I know this is obviously today probably the hottest debated topic. We will try to be as transparent as we can. We avoided applying an approach where we say, "Well, you know, if the world gets better, then things will look more pretty." I think that's clear that that would then happen. We are looking at the world as it presents itself right now. There are certain forward prices you can see and we are also seeing developments in the operational business, which I will comment on. And that's what we are trying to reflect in our comments on 2009 and 2010.

We clearly have to recognize that there are more uncertainties than what we have seen the years before. I dare to say that no one here in this room or on the phone will come up with a firm view on when the economic crisis ends, and that uncertainty simply will -- you will see -- will be reflected in our numbers.

At Group level, we expect adjusted EBIT to be at the 2008 level. Adjusted net income, expect to be around 10% below 2008. And I know, it has been asked for how can that be, why is that happening? With EBIT being more or less flat, our net interest result will deteriorate and just to give you some of the ingredients for that, when you look at the end of last year, you have roughly gross debt of say €40 billion. I think we have highlighted through the markets that we tend to pay some 5.2 to 5.4% on our debt position.

We have, on the other hand, roughly 10 billion of cash or similar assets and there we earn in these environments probably more something like 2.5, 3,3.5%, and then you should also factor into this 50 billion of nuclear provisions and that portion in our pension service -- in pension obligations that is not funded where the charge is roughly 6%. If you factored all those numbers together, you -- I think that should give you some indication. Tax rate, we see roughly at the level of 25 to 27% going forward.

Let me now go into the different market units and you will remember we didn't do that last year. This year given you will be able to compare it on a like-for-like basis, we'd like to give some indications and also highlight what we see to be the main effect.

Central Europe, we expect to be up compared to 2008. Main effects we see here higher achieved wholesale prices in the order of magnitude of roughly of 4 to €5 per megawatt hour. We, at this stage, assume that Krümmel the nuclear plant will be available for the second half of 2008. We'll have to see whether that in the end materializes or not. As you know we are not the operator of that plant, but we'll have to make some assumptions.

We clearly see in our Central European business potential first impacts from the economic crisis, and here that can be in particular lower volumes and they're specifically not in the -- with household customers but with industrial customers, smaller medium term -- small and medium enterprises, which -- some of them may go out of business, some of them may have a contract where a certain volume is fixed but maybe not 100% and hence we think we run the risk of losing some volumes in that business.

And then finally we also see in Central Europe a risk that the cost increases that we see in our German grids, in particular for network losses and having to buy balancing power that those will not be allowed to immediately pass on with tariffs in this year but potentially only with a time delay. This is still under discussion with the regulator, but that clearly is a risk that we see.

Pan-European Gas, we expect to be down compared to 2008, I highlighted that we think 2008 was a peak year. In particular, the gas upstream business, where we're not hedged, is essentially following – or is breathing with the oil price. We see it roughly break-even at today's oil prices.

We also expect to see a hit compared to 2008 and we've been saying that almost exactly a year ago in this very same room in our gas transportation business from moving to cost plus regulation. We don't yet have sort of the final results from the discussion with the regulator but those will be effective then for this year. That will likely partially be offset with consolidation of EBIT from Yuzhno Russkoye in the second half of this year.
U.K., we expect to be down, I highlighted that earlier, it's in particular the pound that's driving that change.

Nordic, here is also a currency effect that will cause, in our prognosis, that business to come down. We also clearly have less EBIT consolidated in our numbers because of having given roughly a third of the hydro capacity to Statkraft, so that's no longer -- that earnings contribution is no longer consolidated within our Group. And that will partially be offset by higher achieved power prices.

U.S. Midwest, stable despite economic downturn. And new markets we expect to be up. In Spain and Italy, clearly we will no longer see this roughly 220 million negative effect from CO2 cost, which we saw in 2008 and we will now consolidate those businesses for the full-year.

We expect also see a higher contribution from our Climate & Renewables business given that the asset base essentially continues to grow almost on a monthly basis. Russia, we think it's going to move primarily sideways in particular given the slowdown in the Russian economy, weaker industrial demand, and in particular also here we see effects from currency movement, i.e., the weak Rubel valuation.

This is in a way looks at almost the same effects, but with a different cut, so I will try to be a little bit quicker here. From a Group perspective, just the highlights. The two main effects that will drive results up is outright power. You see here, gives you some indication what the key data are and is the impact from new markets. And the things that will be driving it down is regulation; gas transport; risk also in the German power grids with a delay in the cost pass-through; currency effects, which is going to be a three digit million number; first effects from the economic crisis, which is primarily our expectation that volumes with industrial customers may come down but maybe also over time things like bad debt that you run into may go up. And then lastly here on that page the gas upstream business where in 2008 we had a very nice result.

Let me now move to the favorite topic of 2010 where we went through a period of many months where we've been bullied to raise that guidance that we put out and we've always been saying, we don't know where commodity prices will be and hence we are not going to adjust that target. We clearly now see that commodity prices are at a very different level, but sort of in the other direction compared to what we have seen for many months in the past two-and-a-half years.

I will try to sort of come to the 2010 guidance from two angles. On the one hand, explain the main deltas compared to the original 12.4 target, and on the other hand, try to kind of build it starting from our prognosis for 2009. The second one, I'll do on the next page.

We always acknowledged that there is upsides in the 12.4 billion target as a result of where commodity prices have been going during the past two years and given our hedging activities, we managed to capture quite some of that upside. To give you an indication, compared to the 2010 forwards that we were seeing back in May 2007, we achieved roughly eight to €10 more per megawatt hour than the forwards were back then.

Ladies and gentlemen, Marcus has indeed talked about '09 and '10, but of course the E.ON story continues and therefore let me provide you with some insights on the perspectives for 2011 and beyond.
And we believe that the current economic crisis will not fundamentally change the dynamics of our industry. We therefore remain optimistic about E.ON's medium and long-term prospects.

In power generation, replacement requirements play a much larger role than demand growth in the balance between supply and demand. The current economic crisis does not change anything to the fact that most of the existing U.K. nuclear fleet will shut down by 2020, for example.

The Large Combustion Plant Directive will also remove coal-fired units in many countries, and the growth of renewables will have to be backed by flexible capacity. The current weakness of demand will therefore have only a limited and temporary effect on the equilibrium of the markets.

Furthermore, we are likely to see the postponement or the cancellation of many new-build projects. We therefore expect power prices and margins to recover during the next decade. We currently have 18 conventional plants under construction. Many will come into service in 2010 and '11 and contribute to earnings growth afterwards.

The recent dispute between Russia and Ukraine has also underlined the strength of our strategy of diversified supplies backed by a solid infrastructure. In the gas business, the development of gas upstream and storage business will provide most of the earnings growth after 2010 and of course the renewable also remains a growth story. The sector might benefit from additional public support as part of so called 'green deals.'

E.ON is rolling out its strategy of driving renewables to industrial levels. We have multiplied our renewable capacity by five in less than 18 months. We are adding about 1 gigawatt of renewable capacity per year and have thus joined the very selected 'Gigawatt Club.' As a result, we expect to reach our own 4 gigawatts of renewable capacity in 2010 and about 10 gigawatt in 2015.

The earnings contribution of our market unit Climate & Renewables will grow rapidly in line with its asset base. Our new markets, especially Russia, should also see strong earnings growth after 2010. The liberalization of the Russian market is scheduled to complete in 2011.

Power prices and spreads should progressively converge to market levels. In addition, the four power plants that will be commissioned there between 2010 and 2012 will add substantial earnings. The extensive commissioning of new power plants, the development for our gas business, the growth of renewables, and the new markets form a substantial number of growth drivers for 2011 adjusted EBIT.

Ladies and gentlemen let me conclude. The last few months have an extremely rapid turnaround of economic fortunes. In all likelihood, 2009 and 2010 will be dominated by the economic crisis. To some extent we had to adjust our strategy and expectations.

Furthermore, by improving our operational performance, streamlining our portfolio, and prioritizing our investments, we are laying solid foundations for E.ON's future growth.

Before we go to Andreas Thielen in the room, we have a question from Ingo Becker from Kepler. On the delays in cost pass-throughs in the grids, are you referring to wholesale costs, in bracket, wholesale power and gas prices, or specific costs in the grids, and is this affecting both power and gas grids?

Just for the avoidance of doubt, this has nothing to do with our retail business. This is our regulated business, the grid businesses in Germany where network losses play a role, and where we also have a cost for having to buy balancing power. And so far, we have a situation where the regulator has granted, I think, a price of €44 compensation, which is far below the price that all grid operators had to pay, and now there is a debate around when that delta can be passed through to higher tariffs. We, and I would assume all other grid operators, are obviously advocating this has to happen immediately, but there could be a time delay and we only get it later, in which case that can be quite a significant charge in 2009, or actually in every year if they don't change the logic.

Further example, in the TSO business, we have more and more renewables in the German system. You need more and more regulatory power to balance the grid, and there we discuss – one theory is that TSO is allowed to pass that through to the DSOs, the distribution system operators, but these distribution system operators may only be allowed to put it on a regulatory account. They have five-year periods. An in the second period, they get it back with interest. But even then, you have the fiscal effect and we have an added effect on the way that has to be recorded in the books.

So there's various effects that not necessarily mean that there's a total loss of anything, but the system in Germany is young. Don't forget in the U.K. we're in the fifth period. The regulatory system is, I would say, adult. Things have been tried out, things have been worked out. Here in Germany, where we have the biggest TSO and DSO business, a lot of things are just maturing and there is debate going onward and forward, so we have to believe that some deferrals happen.
